articles.title: Next.js 14 Released
articles.description: Unveiled at last week‚Äôs Next.js Conf, v14 caused a lot of community discussion (not least on Hacker News), largely surrounding Server Actions being declared stable and the 'backend-meets-frontend' opportunities this opens up. A new partial prerendering feature is also in preview, allowing for dynamic responses but with the speed of an initial static response.
articles.author: Lee Robinson and Tim Neutkens

articles.title: Remix ‚ù§Ô∏è Vite: Remix 2.2 Introduces Vite Support
articles.description: Remix is a popular full-stack JavaScript framework that began as a paid product, but has been open source for two years now. If you found Remix‚Äôs compilation approach opaque before, we have great news: ‚ÄúWith Vite, Remix is no longer a compiler. Remix itself is just a Vite plugin.‚Äù This post tells the full story.
articles.author: Cattori and Dalgleish (Remix)

articles.title: Speeding Up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Tailwind CSS
articles.description: Marvin‚Äôs ongoing journey to improve our ecosystem by finding low-hanging performance-bearing fruit continues with a look at how the architecture of Tailwind CSS could be tuned.
articles.author: Marvin Hagemeist

articles.title: A New Way to Bring Garbage Collected Languages Efficiently to WebAssembly
articles.description: WasmGC is a new and promising way to implement GC languages in WebAssembly and it‚Äôs now enabled by default in Chrome.
articles.author: Alon Zakai (V8)

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Your Website Does Not Need JavaScript
articles.description: An hour long talk in which Amy builds a completely static website ‚Äî using a collection of HTML and CSS files with no tracking, no scripting, no servers, and no third-party resources.
articles.author: Amy Kapernick

articles.title: Building a Generic RSS Parser Service with Cloudflare Workers
articles.description: Ray walks through various iterations and improvements in trying to build an RSS parser that can work in the Workers environment.
articles.author: Raymond Camden

articles.title: Can Next.js Handle 5000 Pages?
articles.description: Christian set out to push both Next.js and AWS Amplify hard. A good read.
articles.author: Christian Nwamba

articles.title: Svelte Flow: Node-Based UI for Svelte
articles.description: From the creators of React Flow comes a Svelte version in the shape of a customizable Svelte component for building node-based editors and interactive diagrams. Check out the examples.
articles.author: webkid GmbH

articles.title: Docusaurus 3.0: Meta's Static Site Generator
articles.description: Docusaurus is a popular React-powered tool aimed at building documentation sites, though it handles more general sites too. v3 features an upgrade to MDX v3, React 18, Mermaid v10, and essentially updates everything.
articles.author: S√©bastien Lorber

articles.title: Hotkey 2.2: Declarative Keyboard Shortcuts for HTML
articles.description: Set a data-hotkey attribute on your elements to quickly add keyboard shortcuts. v2.2 improves Mac alt/option support.
articles.author: GitHub

articles.title: Is Text or Binary? 7.0
articles.description: This library first tries to determine from a filename if the contents of the associated file are likely to be binary or text. Failing that, it can then look at the actual data to figure it out.
articles.author: Bevry

articles.title: <browser-window>: A Web Component to Create Pretend Browser Windows on the Web
articles.description: A lightweight themed zero-dependency web component wrapper to emulate a Safari-like browser window within a Web page. The page full of demos might give you some ideas for its use.
articles.author: Zach Leatherman

articles.title: lossless-json: Parse JSON Without Losing Numeric Information
articles.description: JSON.parse can trip over when it comes to large numbers, so this library parses numeric values not as regular numbers but in a lightweight lossless way keeping the value as a string.
articles.author: Jos de Jong

articles.title: Vueform: An Open Source Form Framework for Vue.js
articles.description: This has been around for a while but is now MIT licensed. Its ancillary form builder app stays commercial, but isn't mandatory for using the library. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Vueform

articles.title: Val Town 3.0: A Social Way to Write and Deploy TypeScript
articles.description: ‚ÄúIf GitHub Gists Could Run, and AWS Lambda Were Fun‚Äù is a fantastic description for this online platform where you write tiny bite size functions (‚Äòval‚Äôs) to be run in V8 isolates. You can connect them together, schedule them, serve them up over HTTP, and more. Version 3 is a big jump for the platform, adding JSX support, more standardized JavaScript approaches to solving problems, and the ability to edit and run your ‚Äòvals‚Äô locally.
articles.author: Steve Krouse

articles.description: Astro 3.4 ‚Äì The Web framework gains page partials, a new experimental dev overlay, and more.

Visual Studio Code October 2023 ‚Äì A couple of minor enhancements to the JS debugger, and Copilot Chat (if you have GitHub Copilot) can now provide better answers because it's sent implementation details behind the symbols you mention.
jQuery 4.0 is 100% feature complete but it's not released just yet.. but we know you can't wait. Ditto for Angular 17 ‚Äì more on that soon.
Rollup 4.2, Cypress 13.4, Ember.js 5.4, Stencil 4.7

articles.title: <browser-window>: A Web Component to Create Pretend Browser Windows on the Web
articles.description: Initially built to use within a slide deck (for this talk), browser-window is a lightweight themed zero-dependency web component wrapper to emulate a Safari-like browser window within a Web page. The page full of demos might give you some ideas for its use.
articles.author: Zach Leatherman

articles.title: Reality Check #1: Building Out a Furniture Site from¬†Dribbble
articles.description: This is a fun new experimental blog series where a visually stunning design is taken from Dribbble and then recreated by a professional Web developer to see how well it might function in practice. This first one is for a furniture site.
articles.author: Andy Bell

articles.title: Answering Common Questions About Interpreting Page Speed¬†Reports
articles.description: This post takes a closer look at how various performance tools both audit and report on various performance metrics (such as core web vitals), and then answers some common questions that arise from running such audits.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: You're Gonna Need A Bigger Browser
articles.description: Yes, browsers are hugely load-bearing in the web‚Äôs architecture, and Robin notes they haven‚Äôt really changed all that much. As such this post questions some aspects that seem worthy candidates for change to best serve the user going forward.
articles.author: Robin Berjon

articles.title: WebKit Features in Safari 17.1
articles.description: Here‚Äôs a rundown of what‚Äôs new. Oh, and 17.2 is already in beta.
articles.author: WebKit

articles.title: The New CSS Math: rem() and mod()
articles.description: Runs through the basics of these two new math functions and highlights some use cases. Dan notes that ‚Äúthe nuance in how they work is not always clear from the start‚Äù ‚Äî so this quick overview should prove handy.
articles.author: Dan Wilson

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Your Website Does Not Need JavaScript
articles.description: An hour long talk in which Amy builds a completely static website ‚Äî using a collection of HTML and CSS files with no tracking, no scripting, no servers, and no third-party resources.
articles.author: Amy Kapernick

articles.title: 'Let‚Äôs Reinvent the Wheel'
articles.description: Musing on how we approach designing the web, highlighting some pain points with current methods, issues with design tools, and what role CSS can play in creating our sites.
articles.author: Vasilis van Gemert

articles.title: Naming Variables in CSS
articles.description: Some conventions that you may want to consider when it comes to naming your CSS variables.
articles.author: Jonathan Dallas

articles.title: Exit Animations
articles.description: Animating an element as it leaves the DOM isn‚Äôt something that‚Äôs particularly straightforward. Here Chris shares some options, before commenting that he hopes something like ‚Äú@exit-style or @exiting-style or @outgoing-style or ::outgoing‚Äù lands in CSS eventually.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: How Blogging Platform Bear Does Analytics with CSS
articles.description: Instead of using server logs this ‚Äúslightly boutique‚Äù analytics system triggers a read with a body:hover CSS declaration.
articles.author: Herman Martinus

articles.title: Making Music with Google Sheets and Web MIDI API
articles.description: A fun curio this ‚Äî with the help of Web MIDI API, we can use Google Sheets as a music sequencer.
articles.author: Asep Bagja

articles.title: Docusaurus 3.0: The Elegant Static Site Generator
articles.description: Docusaurus is a popular React-powered tool aimed at building documentation sites in particular, though it can handle more general sites too. Folks like Supabase, Redux and Temporal use it for their doc sites. v3 features an upgrade to MDX v3, React 18, Mermaid v10, and essentially modernizes everything.
articles.author: S√©bastien Lorber

articles.title: Tiny Helpers: Online Tools for Web Developers
articles.description: We first featured this now sizeable collection of single-purpose online tools around three years ago, and it has since grown to over 500 resources. It has plenty of tools aimed at developers of all types ‚Äî think things like color management, favicon generators, accessibility tools, and more.
articles.author: Stefan Judis

articles.title: Nightwind: Automatic Dark Mode for Tailwind¬†Sites
articles.description: An innovative and customizable Tailwind plugin that takes your current color choices into consideration when constructing a dark mode theme for your site. Try it out directly on the page.
articles.author: Nightwind

articles.title: TailwindMate: Convert CSS Colors to and from Tailwind Format
articles.description: Enter any CSS color (RGBA, HSLA, hex) and this tool will convert the color to the closest Tailwind named equivalent. You can also switch to ‚Äúfrom Tailwind‚Äù mode.
articles.author: Jaleel Bennett

articles.title: SiriWave: The Apple Siri Waveform Replicated in Pure JS
articles.description: If you need an effect that implies sound is playing or being recorded, perhaps.
articles.author: Flavio Maria De Stefano

articles.title: FormsLab: An Open-Source Form Builder Toolkit for Creating Surveys, Polls, and More
articles.author: Konrad Ryczko

articles.description: ‚≠êÔ∏è Yikes. None of the 100 most-visited websites globally uses HTML in full conformance with the HTML spec, though a few get very close.
The first ever State of React survey is now live and invites you to both test your React knowledge and share your thoughts on the React ecosystem.
Google's journey to mobile-first indexing is now complete.
Mozilla shares some details on how improvements have been made to the speed of Firefox this year.
In other Mozilla news, folks using Debian-based Linux distros are now being provided with Firefox Nightly .deb packages.
Automattic's WooCommerce is rebranding as just 'Woo'.
